notes.note: Starting with Firefox 146, in Nightly, you can now right-click any tab and add a quick note to it, making it easier to keep track of what you were doing without needing an extension.
Starting with Firefox 147, Nightly and Beta builds (b6 and earlier) have improved support for screen readers accessing mathematical formulas embedded in PDFs.

[Firefox for Android][1] introduces a refreshed toolbar with a modern design and improved customization support.


  [1]: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.fenix

[Firefox for Android][1] now includes a "Copy link text" context menu item to copy the text associated with a link.


  [1]: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.fenix

Starting with Firefox 148, Split View is enabled in Nightly builds. You can view two tabs side-by-side in a single window, making it easier to compare information, research topics, or work across multiple pages at once. You can create a Split View directly from a tab’s context menu.

The initial empty document is now Web-compatible: if the first navigation of a browsing context goes to about:blank, it completes synchronously and is no longer replaced by a second parser-generated document.

Starting with Firefox 147, Nightly and Beta builds (b6 and earlier) now support the [Sanitizer API][1], which provides new methods for HTML manipulation. The `element.setHTML()` [method][2] enables developers to insert HTML content similarly to `element.innerHTML`, but without the security vulnerabilities such as cross-site scripting (XSS). A complementary method, `document.parseHTML()`, is also available for parsing HTML safely.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Sanitizer
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Element/setHTML

Firefox now supports the [Trusted Types API][1], which is primarily aimed at preventing cross-site scripting attacks.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Trusted_Types_API

Firefox now supports the CSS [shape()][1] function, which allows defining responsive free-form shapes in properties that take shapes like [clip-path][2]. It has some advantages over the [path()][3] function, as it utilizes standard CSS syntax, supports various CSS units, and enables the use of mathematical functions.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/basic-shape/shape
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/clip-path
  [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/CSS/basic-shape/path

Starting with Firefox 148, Nightly builds now support the [Document Picture-in-Picture API][1], which allows web pages to place content in an always-on-top popup.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Document_Picture-in-Picture_API

Firefox now supports the [Element.setHTML()][1] and [Document.parseHTML()][2] functions, to safely set or parse HTML with a built-in sanitizer. This can help prevent Cross-Site Scripting vulnerabilities. Firefox also supports the [Sanitizer()][3] constructor to configure the HTML sanitization.


  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Element/setHTML
  [2]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Document/parseHTML_static
  [3]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Sanitize

The [joint iteration proposa][1]l adds new Iterator.zip and Iterator.zipKeyed methods that allow zipping together underlying iterators into an iterator over values grouped by position, similar to zip in many other languages.


  [1]: https://github.com/tc39/proposal-joint-iteration

Starting with Firefox 146, added support for calling [showPicker()][1] on text-based `<input>` elements with an associated `<datalist>`, allowing programmatic display of autofill suggestions for users on Nightly builds or Beta builds (b6 and earlier).

  [1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/HTMLInputElement/showPicker#showpicker_for_a_datalist_input
On Windows, dragging a downloaded image to Adobe Illustrator now properly drops an image instead of the image's URL.

system_requirements:
## Windows

### Operating Systems (32-bit and 64-bit)
 - Windows 10 or later

### Recommended Hardware
-  1 gigahertz (GHz) or faster compatible processor or System on a Chip (SoC)
-  1GB of RAM / 2GB of RAM for the 64-bit version
-  500MB of hard drive space

---

## Mac

### Operating Systems
- macOS 10.15 or later

### Recommended Hardware
- Macintosh computer with an Intel x86 or Apple silicon processor
- 512 MB of RAM
- 200 MB hard drive space

---

## GNU/Linux

### Software Requirements

*Please note that GNU/Linux distributors may provide packages for your distribution which have different requirements.*

- Firefox will not run at all without the following libraries or packages:
    - glibc 2.17 or higher (2.28 or higher on arm64)
    - GTK+ 3.14 or higher
    - libglib 2.42 or higher
    - libstdc++ 4.8.1 or higher (6.0 or higher on arm64)
    - X.Org 1.0 or higher (1.7 or higher is recommended)
- For optimal functionality, we recommend the following libraries or packages:
    - DBus 1.0 or higher
    - NetworkManager 0.7 or higher
    - PulseAudio
text:
Firefox Nightly gets updated every day and as a consequence, the release notes for the Nightly channel are updated continuously to reflect features that have reached sufficient maturity to benefit from community feedback and bug reports. 

**Warning: Features listed here may or may *not* make a final release of Firefox.**

In addition to these release notes, you can follow ongoing development on our [@FirefoxNightly][1] Bluesky account, our [@FirefoxNightly][4] Mastodon account as well as read our [Nightly Blog][2].

You can interact with other Firefox Nightly users and give your feedback to Mozilla staff in the [Nightly Matrix room][3] on chat.mozilla.org.


  [1]: https://bsky.app/profile/firefoxnightly.bsky.social
  [2]: https://blog.nightly.mozilla.org
  [3]: https://chat.mozilla.org/?#/room/#nightly:mozilla.org
  [4]: https://mastodon.social/@FirefoxNightly
title: Firefox 148.0a1 Nightly
